Award.AwardTitle: Center for Advancing Research and Communication in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (ARC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal creates a Diffusion and Evaluation Center for the Research in Education and Evaluation in Science and Engineering (REESE) program. Specifically, this Center:
1. Provides support and capacity building opportunities for the REESE PIs through technical assistance that strengthens methodological and analytic approaches;
2. Creates opportunities for dialogue and interaction through PI and other themed meetings, online resources, and provides mechanisms for PIs to share instrumentation, data and findings;
3. Produces studies and reports based on various aspects of the REESE portfolio through (in consultation with NSF) identifying criteria to assess the rigor of studies and provide information on the effectiveness of the program and the studies it supports;
4. Summarizes key findings of REESE projects to various audiences such as researchers, policymakers, and practitioners;
5. Contributes to the creation of an evaluation framework for the REESE program, and
6. Conducts original research on salient issues related to the portfolio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Advancing Research and Communication in STEM (ARC) was a National Science Foundation initiative funded in 2008 to support NSF’s program for Research and Evaluation on Education in Science and Engineering (REESE). ARC worked closely with NSF and REESE projects to identify opportunities to support both individual research initiatives and the program as a whole.  Key activities undertaken in support of REESE projects included: conducting personal in-depth needs assessment interviews with REESE investigators; responding to requests for technical assistance; providing a mechanism for REESE projects to update structured abstracts and reports on project findings, leveraging opportunities to utilize these data to highlight key project and programmatic findings; and a range of community-building activities, including collaborating with program officers to convene periodic principal investigator (PI) meetings.  Additionally, ARC pursued an integrated program of original research, special evaluative studies, and related activities in furtherance of REESE program goals. For example, ARC sustained a multi-year program of work on two initiatives focused on measuring the impact of the REESE program and factors affecting the underrepresentation of women in STEM. Evidence of the Center’s success in achieving each of these goals is contained in a final summative evaluation report and is summarized below:

Providing Technical Assistance

Overall, ARC was able to provide technical support through a variety of mechanisms that administrative data indicates has built the capacity of REESE investigators to conduct rigorous research and communicate their findings. The Center’s structured abstract initiative was an effective strategy for collecting uniform information about more than 400 projects that could be used to both produce useful information about the REESE portfolio and gather information about the technical assistance (TA) needs of individual projects and the community as a whole. While very resource intensive, the needs assessment interviews provided critical information for developing TA resources and planning PI meetings. However, the interviews themselves surfaced relatively few “urgent” requests for assistance from individual projects and thus may not have been a cost-effective mechanism for identifying specific project needs, particularly given the size of the REESE community. Finding more efficient ways of identifying collective needs and delivering TA via group activities and one-on-one consultations at PI meetings, which received uniformly high ratings, may prove to be the most efficient way for a support center to provide assistance to a large community of research projects.

Building a REESE Community

Feedback from REESE investigators suggests that PI meetings continue to be an effective mechanism for networking and sharing ideas. The previous section also highlighted the importance of PI meetings to support centers as a venue for delivering technical assistance and for eliciting information from projects such as the structured abstracts that ARC used to create online project summaries. Furthermore, results of statistical analyses show that having a Center website for an entire NSF program enhances the broader impacts of both individual projects and the program as a whole. Important to this dissemination effort is the use of structured abstract information that provides users with consistent information across project descriptions and facilitates efficient searching. Analysis of web usage data shows that these online summaries are more likely to be viewed if they include information about findings and publications, and such analyses also enable the Center to provide information back to NSF that might be helpful in future funding decisions.
